questions.text: As part of a public outreach initiative under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment, you are screening the population of a neighboring village. While preparing your report, what definition of blindness would you use?

choices.text: Presenting distance visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye
Presenting distance visual acuity less than 1/60 in the better eye
Presenting distance visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye
Presenting distance visual acuity less than 2/60 in the better eye

questions.solution:
The definition of blindness under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI) is presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye and limitation of the field of vision to less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation.

Note:

Previously, the definition of blindness under the NPCB was a visual acuity of less than 6/60 in the better eye. However, it has been modified to adopt the World Health Organisation (WHO) definition of a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of preventable childhood blindness?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency.

The most common cause of blindness (including adults), is however, cataract.

questions.text:
You have examined five patients(i-v) in the OPD this morning. Their visual acuity test results are as given below. Who amongst them would be described as blind as per the WHO Vision 2020 definition?

   i.  Best-corrected visual acuity less than 3/60 in the worse eye.
  ii. Presenting visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye.
  iii. Presenting visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye.
  iv. Visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.
  v. Visual field loss of greater than 10° in the better eye.
questions.solution:
Patients iii and iv would be classified as blind. 

In the Vision 2020 initiative, the WHO has revised its definition of blindness. As per the new definition,

"Blindness is defined as a presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye."

Note: Blindness is defined for the better eye, hence option (i) is insufficient information to classify as blind, as information about the better eye is not given.

questions.solution:

questions.text:
Match the findings of the given patients (i, ii, iii, iv) with the appropriate category of blindness they fall under.

i. Unable to count fingers at 6m 

ii. Vision 1/60 to the perception of light

iii. Best-corrected visual acuity less than 3/60

iv. No perception of light 

 

A. Absolute blindness

B. Economic blindness 

C. Manifest blindness 

D. Social blindness
questions.solution:
Type of Blindness Description
Social Blindness Presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 (20/400) in the better eye and limitation of the field of vision to be less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation
Economic blindness The inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 6 meters
Manifest blindness Vision 1/60 to just perception of light
Absolute blindness No perception of light
Curable blindness That stage of blindness where the damage is reversible by prompt management, e.g., cataract
Preventable blindness Loss of vision that could have been completely prevented by the institution of effective preventive or prophylactic measures e.g.,  xerophthalmia, trachoma, and glaucoma 
Avoidable blindness The sum total of preventable and curable blindness is often referred to as avoidable blindness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Nigerian man hailing from an area endemic for river blindness presented with the given finding. What is the drug of choice for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The image shows sclerosing keratitis of onchocerciasis or river blindness. The drug of choice for the treatment of onchocerciasis is ivermectin. 

Ivermectin: 6 mg, single-dose, repeated every 6-12 months, according to the weight of the patient. 

Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were given in the past but have been discontinued due to serious adverse effects.

questions.text: You are appointed as the regional doctor in charge of overseeing the activities under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK). All of the following diseases are specifically covered under the purview of this program except?
questions.solution:
Congenital glaucoma is not covered under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Child health screening and early intervention services under RBSK envisages to cover 30 selected health conditions for screening, early detection, and free management in the age group birth to 18 years. The eye conditions that are covered are

  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Congenital cataract
  • Vision impairment
  • Retinopathy of prematurity
